array.string: The two white circles at the bottom represent "experiments". Tap them to "do experiments".
Experiments generate small white circles that move up the screen, called "experiences". Each experience has a numerical "value" displayed on its right.
Your score (top left behind this window) is the sum of the values of your last ten experiences. Try to reach 10 before moving on to the next level.
An experience is the association of a performed experiment with an obtained "result".
In Level 1, experiments are represented by different shapes, and results by different colors.
When you have reached the score of 10, tap the "cloud" icon that appears above the robot to see the effects produced by the experiments in an imaginary world.
Experiments may produce different experiences depending on the "state of the world" in which they are performed. They may also change the state of the world.
Experiences that have a positive value are considered "enjoyable", and those that have a negative value "unpleasant".
Try to generate a sequence of enjoyable experiences.
Long-press an experiment to change its shape. This will also change the shape of the experiences generated by this experiment.
Long-press an experience to change its color. This will also change the color of the other experiences produced by the same experiment and having the same result.
Shapes and colors are purely illustrative. Changing them will not affect the behavior of experiments and the value of experiences.
In the world of Level 4, you cannot always avoid unpleasant experiences.
Just generate a sequence that contains as few unpleasant experiences as possible.
Displaying enjoyable experiences in green and unpleasant experiences in red may help you to see regularities.

Observe the effects of experiments when you try to use them alone several times in a row. One of them always produces the same experiences in a given state of the world. It is called a "persistent experiment".
This persistent experiment allows you to observe the state of the world without modifying it.
The colors of experiences may help you to identify the states of the world that afford enjoyable experiences.
In Level 6, experiments have the same effects as in Level 5, but they have been rearranged in a random order, and are all initially represented by circles.
It is left to you to attribute the green and red colors to experiences, and the square and triangle shapes to experiments on the basis of the effect they produce.
Try to choose the same shapes and colors as in Level 5. Playing again Level 5 may be useful.
In Level 7, experiments have the same effects as in Levels 5 and 6, but some experiences have different values.
You may attribute the green color to experiences that are enjoyable or that make you hope an enjoyable experience on the next round.
You may attribute the red color to experiences that are unpleasant or that make you fear an unpleasant experience on the next round.
On Level 8, experiences have the same effects and the same values as in Level 7.
However, the experiment represented by a circle always produces the same experience. This experiment thus provides no unformation. It is nonetheless usefull to change the state of the world.
On level 9, the experiments have the same immediate effects as in Levels 5, 6, 7, and 8, but they also change the world on the long term.
Once the world has been appropriately changed, you can obtain an enjoyable experience on each round.
The world of Level 10 is the same as that of Level 9, and experiences have the same values.
As in Level 8, there is an experiment that always produces the same experience but changes the state of the world.
